title: Jessica S. Guo
text:
Jessica Guo is a data scientist at the University of Arizona and a plant ecophysiologist at the Desert Botanical Garden. She blends her passion for data science education and expertise in desert plant water use to ask:

How do plants balance twin demands for water and carbon?
what are the impacts of plant water use strategies for whole ecosystems?



Northern Arizona University Flagstaff, AZ
Ph.D. in Biological Sciences | 2019
M.S. in Biological Sciences | 2013
Arizona State University Tempe, AZ
Certificate in Statistics | 2015
Columbia University New York, NY
B.A. in Environmental Biology | 2010

title: Research
text:
Species coexistence under water limitation
Do co-existing plants partition water resources as suggested by species coexistence theory? In my early attempt to blend community ecology with plant ecophysiology, I addressed this question by comparing stem and soil water isotopes along an elevation gradient in Northern Arizona, ranging from the upland Sonoran Desert to the spruce-fir forests in the San Francisco Peaks. By calculating niche overlap with output from a Bayesian mixture model, we found that plants in more arid ecosystems do indeed have less overlap between species pairs than plants in more mesic ecosystems.
